node.title: Syphilis contact tracers overwhelmed as infection spreads
node.alt: The back of a man with syphilis reveals numerous lesions
node.description: While attention remains fixed on COVID-19, another, much older disease has been making a rapid resurgence, especially in remote Western Australia.
node.content:
["As syphilis cases continue to surge in Western Australia, contact tracers say they are overwhelmed, with remote areas with high Indigenous populations of particular concern.", "Increased notifications associated with the outbreak of the sexually transmitted infection (STI) were first reported in the Kimberley region in 2014 and have\u00a0spread throughout WA.", "Health experts say while attention remains on COVID-19, syphilis rates are climbing without enough public awareness, especially among Indigenous populations where social stigma discourages people from getting tested.", "In the\u00a0Kimberley, contact tracers are struggling to reach long lists of people who may have caught the STI. The infection\u00a0can cause serious life-long health complications,", "The contact tracers' task is further complicated by a region with a high transient population.", "Ord Valley Aboriginal Health Service sexual health nurse Rosie Jack is based in Kununurra and said syphilis rates were climbing in the Kimberley, with almost 500 cases detected since 2014.", "\"Unfortunately, with other diseases getting a bit more of a voice \u2014 for example COVID \u2014 it means syphilis has taken a back seat\u00a0even though it is a serious condition.\"", "
'The great pretender'
", "Ms Jack said a huge part of her work was encouraging people to get tested without symptoms because syphilis was so difficult to detect.", "\"It's called the great pretender, because it mimics a lot of other diseases. So, it's really important you still get tested even if you don't notice anything,\" she said.", "She said the STI can cause serious life-long complications.", "\"What I'm really concerned about with syphilis is women contracting it during pregnancy because it does get passed onto the baby,\" the sexual health nurse said.", "", "
Anne Clarke and\u00a0Rosie Jack\u00a0have been spreading the word throughout Kununurra that there's no shame in getting tested.(ABC News: Ted O'Connor)
", "Miriwoong Gajerrong girl Anne Clarke, 16, is a health programs trainee at OVAHS and has been helping Ms Jack spread the message in her cultural community.", "She encouraged people to come to OVAHS and get tested if they wanted more privacy.", "\"I reckon they should come to the hospital rather than (health workers) coming to you because it will make it more awkward,\" Anne said.", "\"If you come to OVAHS, they're (family) are not going to know because OVAHS will keep it a secret.\"", "
'Need more resources'
", "Goldfields public health physician Charles Douglas said rates have increased by 48 per cent in WA's Indigenous population this year.", "He said good public education programs were the best prevention.", "\"Making\u00a0people aware of syphilis, how easy it is to treat.\u00a0 And of course, to prevent syphilis, we need people to be practicing safe sex,\" he said.", "", "
Education is seen as a key way to break down the stigma of getting tested.(ABC News: Ted O'Connor)
", "Australian Health Council of Western Australia\u00a0sexual health and blood-borne virus officer Veronica Walshe said while government-funded education programs and rapid on-the-spot testing had shown success, the STI\u00a0continued to spread."]
